raw_text:
Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal
 
 Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover.
 
 The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, after Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The US firm is thought to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off Fiat's finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort.
 
 The 2000 deal resulted from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat. The German firm wanted to buy Fiat outright. But Gianni Agnelli, the godfather of the group, wanted to keep control, and preferred GM's offer to buy a 20% stake and give Fiat the right to sell in the future, known as a "put option". Since then, however, Fiat cars have lost market share and the firm has piled up losses, while a plan to raise new money in 2003 cut GM's stake in half to 10%. For its part, GM's European units Opel and Saab have both had trouble, with Opel management threatening to cut 12,000 jobs. "The last thing they need is additional production capacity in Europe," said Patrick Juchemich, auto analyst at Sal Oppenheim Bank.
llama3.2:1b:
Fiat and General Motors (GM) are set to settle a potential takeover by midnight on February 1 due to the deadline marking the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM.

The deal was agreed in 2000 as part of an alliance between the two companies, but GM has since become unprofitable and wants to extricate itself from the arrangement. Fiat is offering approximately $2 billion to settle the dispute.

The agreement resulted from a race for control between GM and DaimlerChrysler, with GM opting for a 20% stake in addition to the right to sell its car division in the future, known as a "put option".
llama3.2:3b: Fiat and General Motors have a deadline of February 1 midnight to settle a dispute over Fiat's car division. GM wants to exit the unprofitable unit due to its struggling European operations. The US firm is offering about $2bn to extricate itself, citing the deal was voided by Fiat selling off its finance arm and halving GM's stake.
gemma2:2b: Fiat and GM have until February 1st to reach an agreement regarding a potential takeover deal. Fiat's car division, previously slated for sale to GM under a 2000 agreement, is now subject to disagreements about the deal's validity.  GM seeks to exit the arrangement after losing money on its European operations and losing some of its stake in Fiat.  The deal, initially between GM and DaimlerChrysler, was settled with a put option that gave Fiat the right to sell its car division if desired.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Fiat-GM deal expires soon on February 1st Deadline nears for GM/Fiat agreement to settle a car division dispute. GM has offered about $2bn to "extricate itself from the arrangement". Fiat shares are down 1.2% after trading up early on Tuesday, following reports of deadlocked talks. EU firms Agnelli and Opel have had trouble in Europe with job losses and reduced production capacity.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Fiat and GM must resolve a takeover dispute by February 1st; Fiat's shares dropped due to potential deal issues earlier this week. The alliance agreement from 2000 remains pending with GM offering up to $2bn in hopes of resolving the deadlock. GM wants out of its stake in Fiat, while Fiat is hesitant to sell after financial difficulties and previous capital-raising efforts that reduced its stake.
qwen2.5:3b: Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal; until midnight on 1 February, Fiat will gain right to sell its car division to GM. GM wants out due to loss-making units and disputes over previous agreement terms. Fiat shares fell after Monday's gains, attributed partly to $2bn offer from GM. The original 2000 deal was a compromise between GM buying 20% stake and Fiat having a future sale option; however, recent financial issues have led to increased tensions. GM’s European operations struggle, adding pressure to the situation.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I've got this query where the user wants me to summarize a given text concisely. Let's see what that text is about.

Alright, reading through it, it's all about a potential take-over between GM and Fiat. The deadline for their deal approaching is near February 1st. They have until midnight there to finalize any disagreements. That makes sense because when two big firms are in an alliance and one wants to divest from the other, timing is crucial.

The text mentions that the deal involved a 2000 race between GM and DaimlerChrysler. GM wanted to take over by buying out the entire group, while Daimler was pushing back with their own interests. The key point here is understanding who was trying to buy which company and how that went down the line.

Fiat's shares dropped a bit on Tuesday after the talks got stalled, but they recovered a bit on Monday when there were hopes of a payoff. GM had to sell its parts because it no longer wanted the unit, so they adjusted their shares accordingly. The US firm is offering around $2 billion to get out of the deal, and GM has argued that the deal was voided after Fiat sold off part of its finance arm and halved its stake.

Fiat's shares lost 1.2%, which shows investors were cautious about its position now. GM faced losses in Europe because their European operations are underperforming. They also tried to raise money, selling a big stake to Opel, which had trouble managing jobs, especially in Germany. GM's analysts think they're on the cusp of restructuring or even going public.

Putting it all together, the summary needs to capture the key points: the deadline approaching, the deal details, GM's financial struggles, the US firm's offer, and GM's financial implications. I need to make sure not to add any extra information that wasn't in the original text but still relevant.
</think>

deadline nears for a take-over between GM and Fiat; deadline until midnight on 1 February to finalize potential agreement; deal involves selling car division from Fiat into GM's alliance since 2000; fiat shares fall briefly after talks stall, recover on Monday when hopes of payoff emerge; gm sells parts due to no longer owning unprofitable unit; us firm offers $2 billion to free itself from arrangement; gm argues deal was voided by fiat's decision to sell finance arm and halve stake; gm lost market share in Europe; gm faced financial losses and job concerns due to restructured European operations.
tinyllama:1.1b: Fiat and General Motors (GM) face a deadline of midnight on February 1 to settle a disagreement over the takeover of Fiat's European operations, reportedly worth $2bn. The two companies have been at odds since 2000 when GM made an offer for Fiat outright or in exchange for a 20% stake in 2011, known as a "put option". However, despite the agreement's success with the financing arm and halving GM's stake, Fiat remains opposed to selling its car division. The deadline marks a crucial moment in the deal, with both parties expected to reach a resolution before it expires on January 31st. Reportedly, Fiat shares were down 1.2% on Tuesday, after Monday's 4% gain following hopes of a payoff.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Fiat-GM deal nearing resolution; Fiat seeks $2 billion as GM halts capital raising

Fiat and General Motors (GM) are reportedly close to settling their disagreement over a potential takeover. The two companies, which are part of the alliance agreed in 2000, will have to agree on an offer by midnight on February 1st. GM has offered to buy a 20% stake in Fiat for $2 billion but Fiat's shares fell 1.2% amid reports that the company may try to renege on its promise to sell off its finance arm and cut GM's stake.

GM insists that it has been offering a deal worth $2 billion over a put option for a 20% stake in Fiat. However, Gianni Agnelli, the Godfather of Fiat, has preferred to keep control of the company and prefer a buy-out outright instead. The deadline is fast approaching; if no resolution is found by then, both companies will have to announce new plans for future investment in Europe.

Fiat's problems with loss making cars and poor performance in their European units, Opel and Saab, are also contributing to the impasse. Both companies have had to cut thousands of jobs as a result, and Patrick Juchemich from Sal Oppenheim Bank thinks that GM may want to step in to prevent further job losses. The situation is expected to be resolved by February 1st, but it remains uncertain whether Fiat will accept GM's offer or push for an alternative solution.
phi:2.7b: Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on February 1 to agree on a potential takeover deal for Fiat's car division. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, as part of an agreement made in 2000. However, GM is considering selling off the unprofitable unit and no longer wants to own it. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat stocks down by 1.2% on Tuesday. The US firm is thought to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. Fiat has argued that the deal was voided by Fiat' decision to sell its finance arm and halve GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted in a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler, with GM wanting to buy Fiat outright but Agnelli preferring GM's offer of buying 20% and giving Fiat the option to sell in the future. However, since then, Fiat has lost market share and accumulated losses, while GM's European units have struggled financially.
orca-mini:3b: Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal as reports of deadlocked talks sent shares down 1.2% on Tuesday after Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. GM is thought to be offering about $2bn to extricate itself from the arrangement, but Fiat argues that the deal was voided by its decision to sell off Fiat's finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort.
hermes3:3b:
Fiat-GM deal deadline approaches
Fiat must sell car division to GM by Feb 1st
GM wants out of unprofitable European unit
Deadlock over deal's voiding due to Fiat's finance sale & capital-raising effort
US firm offers $2bn for extraction from the arrangement
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Fiat and General Motors have until midnight on 1 February to resolve a disagreement over a potential takeover. Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM if they settle this deadlock. Reports of deadlocked talks caused Fiat shares to drop 1.2%. GM is offering around $2bn (£1.06bn) to exit the arrangement, arguing that the deal was voided due to Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The original deal in 2000 was part of a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.
stablelm2:1.6b: Fiat and General Motors must settle their dispute over a potential takeover by February 1st or allow Fiat to sell its car division. This deal resulted from competition between GM and DaimlerChrysler, with the latter preferring GM's offer due to its outright acquisition of Fiat. However, Fiat cars have lost market share and suffered losses, causing Gianni Agnelli's preference for GM's stake purchase option instead of complete control. The deadline is approaching as GM wants $2 billion to extricate itself from the arrangement.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on February 1 to finalize a takeover deal, following a disagreement over Fiat's unprofitable European operations. GM, which has been struggling with its own European units, aims to sell its stake in Fiat, offering approximately $2 billion for the transaction. The 2000 alliance, resulting from a rivalry between GM and DaimlerChrysler, granted Fiat a "put option" to sell its car division to GM in the future. However, recent market shifts have led Fiat's shares to fluctuate, with a 4% increase on Monday followed by a 1.2% drop due to deadlocked talks. The deal's viability is questioned as both parties grapple with financial challenges: Fiat's cars have lost market share and incurred losses, while GM's European operations, including Opel, face job cuts threatening 12,000 positions. Analyst Patrick Juchemich of Sal Oppenheim Bank highlights that additional production capacity in Europe would be detrimental to GM's struggling European units.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Fiat and General Motors (GM) face a 1 February deadline to resolve a dispute over Fiat's right to sell its car division to GM, part of a 2000 alliance. GM, struggling with losses in Europe, wants to avoid acquiring Fiat's unprofitable unit and is reportedly offering $2 billion to exit the deal. GM argues the agreement was voided when Fiat sold its finance arm and reduced GM's stake. The original deal stemmed from competition between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat, with GM securing a 20% stake and Fiat retaining a future sale option. Since then, Fiat has lost market share and incurred losses, while GM's European brands Opel and Saab also face difficulties, making additional production capacity undesirable.
reference: Since then, however, Fiat cars have lost market share and the firm has piled up losses, while a plan to raise new money in 2003 cut GM's stake in half to 10%.The German firm wanted to buy Fiat outright.The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed in 2000.The 2000 deal resulted from a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to ally with Fiat.GM, whose own European operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit.
